Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Investigating Heterochromatin Assembly through Histone Deacetylases

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The way that the genome of a cell is "packaged" inside the nucleus directly impacts genome stability and DNA-templated processes such as gene expression and replication necessary for cell division. Highly condensed DNA structures are inhibitory to such processes, and their formation is a critical part of regulatory mechanisms. Despite the important biological roles, little is known about how regions of highly condensed DNA, called heterochromatin, form. This CAREER project will elucidate and compare the molecular pathways necessary for the formation and propagation of functionally distinct heterochromatin domains. Exploiting unique features of the ciliate model Tetrahymena thermophila, Dr. Wiley and a team of undergraduate students will specifically explore the role of histone deacetylase (HDAC) enzymes in heterochromatin formation by determining their spatial and temporal localization and by analyzing mutant cells. Using HDACs as molecular handles, students will employ standard molecular techniques to isolate and identify proteins that bind to them in complexes and further analyze these proteins as candidate components of the pathways. The project's design will significantly increase the number of undergraduates participating in original research. Locally, the work will serve as the foundation of a new laboratory course for sophomore level students, and for numerous mentored student research projects. To extend the research opportunities to undergraduate students at other institutions, the relevant protocols and methods will be packaged and disseminated as classroom laboratory activities for easy integration into existing curricula. Student researchers from all institutions involved will disseminate and discuss their results with the broader scientific community through an interactive website/database linked to the Tetrahymena Genome Database at Stanford University.

This project contributes directly to our understanding of a central question in molecular biology that underlies processes essential for life -- how genomes portray and regulate the information that governs cell characteristics. It will enhance our understanding of genome dynamics, make important contributions to the annotation of a recently sequenced genome, and will also provide to the larger scientific community, valuable reagents for further genome research. Through this multi-institutional initiative, many teams of students will participate in the collaborative research network and be part of a powerful scientific learning community based on the excitement of original research, all at an important time when they are making career decisions. This experience should encourage students to persist in their science education and be particularly supportive of historically underrepresented groups. Increasing the accessibility of science for all students is critical to ensuring future technological advancements and continued economic vitality upon which our high standard of living and the development of other nations depend.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Genome DNA is organized in different ways inside the cell nucleus – some regions are highly compacted into dense structures, and other regions more loosely compacted.  The degree of compaction influences the processing of DNA, such as the "reading" of genetic information, its transmission through generations, and damage repair. Mistakes in compacting different regions of the genome underlie a variety of cellular problems and human health conditions. With this award, we investigated the function of specific proteins called histone deacetylases in establishing, maintaining, and changing degrees of genome compaction. We also studied their impact on regulating the reading of genes, and on genome structure changes that normally happen as a cell develops.  We made several key discoveries that have advanced our understanding of cellular mechanisms for regulating genome compaction: 1) That compacting DNA to a higher degree may involve changing the rate of synthesis and degradation of histone proteins, which form a structure that DNA spools around for compaction. This cycling is influenced by an enzyme (called a histone deacetylase), which removes chemical groups from the histone proteins; 2) That the action of a specific identified histone deacetylase is required for maintaining the compaction and integrity of the genome after DNA is replicated in preparation for cell division; 3) We found evidence that another histone deacetylase may promote the normal elimination of a nucleus during cell development, and controls changes in genome compaction and gene expression that are normally induced when cells are placed in nutrient-poor conditions.  Together, these findings improve our understanding of how genome compaction changes occur, how these processes are regulated, and their significance to cellular life.  These discoveries were published in three peer-reviewed publications.

 

Broader Impacts

This award funded different mechanisms to increase undergraduate student access to training in authentic research. The research activities of this award formed the bases of senior thesis projects for 35 students; independent research for 28 students; and summer research for 21 students. In addition, the activities were imported into the classroom, as the laboratory component for mutiple offerings of a sophomore-level molecular research course (developed from this award) and upper division molecular biology with laboratory course (138 students, total).  Eleven students presented their results at research conferences by giving talks or presenting posters, three won awards for best presentations. Eight students were co-authors on peer-reviewed publications from this award, and three were authors of a book chapter on poster presentations from their training.

To further broaden undergraduate access to authentic research opportunities, the Ciliate Genomics Consortium was conceived and developed under this award (see consortium website, http://tet.jsd.claremont.edu). This consortium of undergraduate biology teachers (currently nine faculty at eleven institutions) collaborated to develop modules directing students in research that explores the functions of genes in the single celled organism Tetrahymena thermophila.
